abstract:
This text describes Method #1247, a procedure used to estimate the percentage of woody riparian cover. The method involves taking measurements at five transects on both banks of a 10mx10m plot, starting at bankfull level. Three types of woody cover are assessed: groundstory (woody shrubs), understory (woody shrubs), and canopy cover (big trees + small trees).

The necessity of this method lies in the importance of understanding the amount of woody riparian cover in various ecosystems. Woody vegetation plays a crucial role in maintaining the health and stability of riparian areas, providing numerous ecological benefits such as erosion control, water quality enhancement, wildlife habitat, and carbon sequestration.

The CHaMP (Continuous Monitoring of Aquatic Resources â€“ Riparian) method, which this estimation procedure is based on, follows the Peck et al. (2001) methods used by the Environmental Management and Assessment Program (EMAP). By implementing a consistent and standardized approach for assessing woody riparian cover, it enables effective comparison of data across different sites and over time.

In summary, this method is an essential tool for evaluating the health and productivity of riparian ecosystems by estimating the percentage of woody cover in these areas. By providing a clear understanding of the distribution and abundance of woody vegetation, it helps inform decision-making related to conservation efforts, restoration projects, and overall management of riparian habitats.

The percentage of woody cover is assessed at five transects (1, 6, 11, 16, 21) positioned on both banks within a 10m x 10m plot, starting from bankfull. Three types of woody cover estimates are provided: groundstory (woody shrubs), understory (woody shrubs), and canopy cover (big trees + small trees). The CHaMP - Riparian Structure Method provides context on the measured variables for this calculation, as outlined in the CHaMP method which adheres to Peck et al. (2001) techniques used by EMAP. For further details about the CHaMP method and its procedures, refer to: http://www.monitoringmethods.org/Method/Details/845.
